news_summary: Today's technology news highlights breakthroughs in AI-driven advancements across biotechnology, archaeology, and earth sciences, alongside cutting-edge laser research pushing material limits.
news_summary_fr: L'actualité technologique d'aujourd'hui met en lumière les avancées de l'IA dans les domaines de la biotechnologie, de l'archéologie et des sciences de la terre, ainsi que la recherche de pointe sur les lasers, qui repousse les limites de la matière.
news_summary_es: Las noticias tecnológicas de hoy destacan los grandes avances en biotecnología, arqueología y ciencias de la tierra impulsados por la inteligencia artificial, así como la investigación láser de vanguardia que supera los límites de los materiales.

articles.title: Integrated biotechnological and AI innovations for crop improvement
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 23 July 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09122-8The integration of omics technologies, genome editing and protein design with artificial intelligence (AI) promises rapid advances in the field of crop improvement that will improve global food security.
articles.content:
van Dijk, M. et al. A meta-analysis of projected global food demand and population at risk of hunger for the period 2010–2050. Nat. Food 2, 494–501 (2021).

Hasegawa, T. et al. Extreme climate events increase risk of global food insecurity and adaptation needs. Nat. Food 2, 587–595 (2021).

Zhang, H. et al. A Gγ protein regulates alkaline sensitivity in crops. Science 379, eade8416 (2023).

Green, J. M. The benefits of herbicide-resistant crops. Pest. Manag. Sci. 68, 1323–1331 (2012).

Lu, Y. et al. Widespread adoption of Bt cotton and insecticide decrease promotes biocontrol services. Nature 487, 362–365 (2012).

Yu, X. et al. Single-cell and spatial multi-omics in the plant sciences: technical advances, applications, and perspectives. Plant Commun. 4, 100508 (2023).

Yu, H. et al. A route to de novo domestication of wild allotetraploid rice. Cell 184, 1156–1170 (2021). This study demonstrates the rapid neo-domestication of wild rice relatives, a new paradigm in enriching crop genetic resources and accelerating crop improvement.

Li, T. et al. Domestication of wild tomato is accelerated by genome editing. Nat. Biotechnol. 36, 1160–1163 (2018).

Qin, P. et al. Pan-genome analysis of 33 genetically diverse rice accessions reveals hidden genomic variations. Cell 184, 3542–3558 (2021).

Tang, D. et al. Genome evolution and diversity of wild and cultivated potatoes. Nature 606, 535–541 (2022). Sequencing and analysis of genomes from wild and cultivated potatoes enables identification of candidate genes for many traits, including a transcription factor for tuber formation.

Liu, Y. et al. Pan-genome of wild and cultivated soybeans. Cell 182, 162–176 (2020).

Hufford, M. B. et al. De novo assembly, annotation, and comparative analysis of 26 diverse maize genomes. Science 373, 655–662 (2021).

Jayakodi, M. et al. Structural variation in the pangenome of wild and domesticated barley. Nature 636, 654–662 (2024).

Jiao, C. et al. Pan-genome bridges wheat structural variations with habitat and breeding. Nature 637, 384–393 (2024).

Sun, W. et al. Genetic modification of Gγ subunit AT1 enhances salt-alkali tolerance in main graminaceous crops. Natl Sci. Rev. 10, nwad075 (2023). This study demonstrates that elite alleles cloned from one crop can be rapidly translated into other crops, facilitated by crop genomics, mutant collections and genome editing.

Varshney, R. K. et al. A chickpea genetic variation map based on the sequencing of 3,366 genomes. Nature 599, 622–627 (2021). This study demonstrates some valuable breeding strategies from sequencing and analysis of cultivated and wild chickpea accessions.

Wei, X. et al. Genomic investigation of 18,421 lines reveals the genetic architecture of rice. Science 385, eadm8762 (2024).

Cheng, S. et al. Harnessing landrace diversity empowers wheat breeding. Nature 632, 823–831 (2024). This study provides a framework for fully utilizing genetic diversity in more than 1,000 wheat landraces and cultivars for wheat improvement through sequencing and in-depth field phenotyping.

Saturated targeted mutagenesis enabled by multiplexed genome editing optimizes the RBL1 allele in balancing immunity and growth, making the unusable allele valuable in rice breeding.

This study develops RoseTTAFold All-Atom and RoseTTAFold diffusion All-Atom, which allow researchers to predict protein–biomolecule complexes and design small molecule binders, respectively.

articles.reasoning: The article highlights a scientific and technological breakthrough integrating biotechnology and AI to improve crops, which promises to enhance global food security. This advancement is likely to have a positive impact on society by addressing food supply challenges.
articles.personality_title: New biotech and AI tools boost crop growth for food security
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
With the world’s population growing and climate change making farming tougher, finding better ways to grow food is more important than ever. Scientists have been working on technologies to help crops grow stronger and produce more food.

**What happened**
Researchers combined biotechnology—like genome editing, which lets scientists change plant DNA precisely—and AI, or artificial intelligence, which helps analyze lots of data quickly. They also used omics technologies, which study all the genes, proteins, or chemicals in plants. Together, these tools speed up how we improve crops.

**Impact**
This smart mix means we can develop crops that resist tough weather, diseases, and poor soil faster than before. It could help prevent hunger by making sure we have enough food worldwide, even as challenges grow.

**What's next step**
Scientists plan to keep improving these methods and start applying them in farms around the world. They will also focus on making these technologies affordable and accessible for farmers everywhere.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Using biotechnology and AI together is a promising way to grow stronger crops and fight global hunger.
articles.personality_title_fr: De nouveaux outils biotechnologiques et d’IA stimulent la croissance des cultures pour la sécurité alimentaire
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Avec la croissance de la population mondiale et le changement climatique qui rend l’agriculture plus difficile, trouver de meilleures façons de cultiver est plus important que jamais. Les scientifiques travaillent sur des technologies pour aider les cultures à devenir plus fortes et produire plus de nourriture.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Les chercheurs ont combiné la biotechnologie — comme l’édition génomique, qui permet de modifier précisément l’ADN des plantes — et l’IA, ou intelligence artificielle, qui aide à analyser rapidement de grandes quantités de données. Ils ont aussi utilisé les technologies omiques, qui étudient tous les gènes, protéines ou substances chimiques dans les plantes. Ensemble, ces outils accélèrent l’amélioration des cultures.

**Impact**
Cette combinaison intelligente permet de développer des plantes résistantes aux conditions météo difficiles, aux maladies et aux sols pauvres plus rapidement qu’avant. Cela pourrait aider à prévenir la faim en assurant assez de nourriture dans le monde même face aux défis.

**Prochaine étape**
Les scientifiques prévoient d’améliorer encore ces méthodes et de commencer à les appliquer dans les fermes partout dans le monde. Ils se concentreront aussi sur rendre ces technologies abordables et accessibles pour tous les agriculteurs.

**Conclusion en une phrase**
Utiliser ensemble la biotechnologie et l’IA est une solution prometteuse pour cultiver des plantes plus fortes et lutter contre la faim mondiale.
articles.personality_title_es: Nuevas herramientas biotecnológicas e IA impulsan el crecimiento de cultivos para la seguridad alimentaria
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Con el crecimiento de la población mundial y el cambio climático que dificulta la agricultura, encontrar mejores maneras de cultivar es más importante que nunca. Los científicos trabajan en tecnologías para ayudar a que los cultivos sean más fuertes y produzcan más alimentos.

**Qué sucedió**
Los investigadores combinaron biotecnología —como la edición del genoma, que permite cambiar el ADN de las plantas con precisión— e inteligencia artificial (IA), que ayuda a analizar muchos datos rápidamente. También usaron tecnologías ómicas, que estudian todos los genes, proteínas o químicos en las plantas. Juntos, estos recursos aceleran la mejora de cultivos.

**Impacto**
Esta combinación inteligente permite crear plantas que resisten mejor el clima extremo, las enfermedades y suelos pobres, más rápido que antes. Esto podría ayudar a prevenir el hambre asegurando suficiente comida en el mundo a pesar de los desafíos.

**Próximo paso**
Los científicos planean seguir mejorando estos métodos y comenzar a aplicarlos en granjas de todo el mundo. También se enfocarán en hacer estas tecnologías accesibles y asequibles para todos los agricultores.

**Resumen en una frase**
Usar biotecnología e IA juntas es una forma prometedora de cultivar plantas más fuertes y combatir el hambre global.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm-toned painting of a thriving crop field where glowing, stylized DNA helixes gently intertwine with sprouting plants under a soft sky, while a network of delicate, glowing circuit patterns weaves subtly through the soil and roots, symbolizing the integration of biotechnology and AI nurturing global crop improvement.

articles.title: Gaps in our knowledge of ancient Rome could be filled by AI
articles.summary: A new system fills in missing words from ancient inscriptions carved on monuments and everyday objects.
articles.content:
Gaps in our knowledge of ancient Rome could be filled by AI

14 hours ago Share Save Pallab Ghosh • @BBCPallab Science Correspondent Share Save

The Metropolitan Museum of Art Artwork: The new system predicts missing text from broken inscriptions, their date and original location

A new AI tool has the potential to turbocharge our understanding of all human history, researchers say. Artificial intelligence has already been used to fill in gaps in ancient Roman scrolls, but a new system goes much further. It can fill in missing words from ancient Roman inscriptions carved on monuments and everyday objects, as well as dating and placing them geographically. AI often introduces errors in its analysis of even simple modern texts, so there are concerns that relying too much on this technology might distort rather than enhance our understanding of history.

But historian Prof Dame Mary Beard of Cambridge University has described the technology as potentially "transformative" to our study of past events. She said that the system, called Aeneas, after a Greek and Roman mythological figure, could accelerate the rate at which historians piece together the past from ancient texts. "Breakthroughs in this very difficult field have tended to rely on the memory, the subjective judgement and the hunch/guesswork of individual scholars, supported by traditional, encyclopaedic databases. Aeneas opens up entirely new horizons."

AtilimGunesBaydin Inscriptions are found on ancient monuments across the globe. This one at the Temple of Augustus in Ankara in Turkey is known as the queen of inscriptions

Ancient inscriptions are usually incomplete, of unknown origin and date, and often all three. Historians and classicists attempt to fill in the blanks by drawing on texts that are similar in wording, grammar, appearance and cultural setting, known as 'parallels'. Ancient inscriptions tend to be formulaic so historians can often infer what the missing part of a sentence goes on to say. The process is painstaking and can take months and years but opens new vistas in our understanding of the past, according to Dr Thea Sommerschield, an historian at Nottingham University, who co-led the research. "Inscriptions are the earliest forms of writing. They are so precious to historians because they offer first-hand evidence for ancient histories, languages and societies. "But they degrade over the centuries and interpreting them is like solving a gigantic jigsaw puzzle with tens of thousands of pieces, of which 90 per cent are lost."

Thea Sommerschield A Roman bronze military diploma dates 94 CE. Like most inscriptions it is incomplete

It's not the first time AI has been used to join up the missing dots in Roman history. Earlier this year, another team of scientists digitally "unwrapped" a badly burnt scroll from the Roman town of Herculaneum using a combination of X-ray imaging and AI, revealing rows and columns of text. Dr Sommerschield developed Aeneas along with her co-research leader Dr Yannis Assael, an AI specialist at Google DeepMind. It automates the process of contextualising based on parallels, in the blink of an eye. Aeneas draws on a vast database of of 176,000 Roman inscriptions including images and uses a carefully designed AI system to pull up a range of relevant historical parallels, to support the work of historians, according to Dr Assael. "What the historian can't do is assess these parallels in a matter of seconds across tens of thousands of inscriptions, and that is where AI can come in as an assistant." The team tested out the system in dating a famous Roman text at the Temple of Augustus in Ankara in Turkey, known as the queen of inscriptions because of its importance to our understanding of Roman history. The Res Gestae Divi Augusti was composed by the first Roman Emperor, Augustus, giving an account of his life and accomplishments. Its date is hotly contested among historians. Aeneas was able to narrow down the options to two possible ranges, the most likely being between 10 and 20 CE and a second slightly less likely range from 10 to 1 BCE. This showed the system's accuracy as most historians agree on these two as the most likely possibilities.

Google Deepmind Artwork: An earlier version of the system filled in missing words in ancient Greek. Aeneas is much more powerful
articles.reasoning: The article highlights a technological advancement where AI is used to fill in missing words from ancient inscriptions, which can significantly enhance our understanding of ancient Rome. This represents a positive use of technology to solve a real problem in historical research and education.
articles.personality_title: AI helps uncover lost words from ancient Roman inscriptions
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Many ancient Roman inscriptions, etched on monuments and everyday objects, have become damaged or incomplete over time. These gaps make it hard for historians to fully understand Roman history.

**What happened**
Scientists have developed a new AI system that can predict missing words in broken inscriptions. This tool looks at the fragments, estimates when they were made, and even guesses their original location.

**Impact**
By filling in the missing pieces, this AI helps historians get a clearer picture of life in ancient Rome. It opens the door to better understanding the culture, language, and events of the time.

**What's next step**
Researchers plan to apply this AI to more ancient texts and objects, broadening our knowledge of human history beyond Rome. They will also refine the system to improve its accuracy.

**One-sentence takeaway**
AI is now helping to bring lost ancient Roman words back to life, enriching our connection to the past.
articles.personality_title_fr: L'IA aide à retrouver les mots perdus des inscriptions romaines anciennes
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
De nombreuses inscriptions romaines anciennes, gravées sur des monuments et des objets du quotidien, sont endommagées ou incomplètes avec le temps. Ces lacunes compliquent la compréhension complète de l'histoire romaine.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Des scientifiques ont développé un nouveau système d'IA capable de prédire les mots manquants dans les inscriptions cassées. Cet outil analyse les fragments, estime leur date et devine leur emplacement d'origine.

**Impact**
En comblant ces blancs, cette IA aide les historiens à mieux comprendre la vie dans la Rome antique. Elle permet de mieux saisir la culture, la langue et les événements de cette époque.

**Étape suivante**
Les chercheurs prévoient d'appliquer cette IA à plus de textes et d'objets anciens, élargissant ainsi nos connaissances de l'histoire humaine au-delà de Rome. Ils vont aussi améliorer la précision du système.

**Conclusion en une phrase**
L'IA aide aujourd'hui à redonner vie aux mots perdus de la Rome antique, renforçant notre lien avec le passé.
articles.personality_title_es: La IA ayuda a recuperar palabras perdidas de inscripciones romanas antiguas
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Muchas inscripciones romanas antiguas, grabadas en monumentos y objetos cotidianos, se han dañado o están incompletas con el tiempo. Estas lagunas dificultan entender completamente la historia romana.

**Qué pasó**
Científicos desarrollaron un nuevo sistema de IA que puede predecir las palabras faltantes en inscripciones rotas. Esta herramienta analiza los fragmentos, estima su fecha e incluso adivina su ubicación original.

**Impacto**
Al llenar los espacios faltantes, esta IA ayuda a los historiadores a obtener una imagen más clara de la vida en la antigua Roma. Abre la puerta para entender mejor la cultura, el idioma y los eventos de esa época.

**Próximo paso**
Los investigadores planean aplicar esta IA a más textos y objetos antiguos, ampliando nuestro conocimiento de la historia humana más allá de Roma. También mejorarán la precisión del sistema.

**Conclusión en una frase**
La IA está ayudando a devolver a la vida las palabras perdidas de la antigua Roma, enriqueciendo nuestra conexión con el pasado.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm-toned painting of ancient Roman stone inscriptions with visible cracks and missing pieces, gently illuminated by a soft light shaped like a glowing, abstract neural network weaving golden threads that connect fragmented letters and symbols, set against a calm, neutral background to symbolize AI piecing together history.

articles.title: Watch the Earth split in real time: Stunning footage reveals a 2. 5-meter fault slip in seconds
articles.summary: A colossal 7.7 magnitude earthquake rocked central Myanmar in March 2025, marking the strongest quake in over a century. What makes this event groundbreaking isn't just the seismic power—it’s the unprecedented footage captured by a CCTV camera near the fault line. Researchers at Kyoto University used this rare video to measure the fault’s movement in stunning detail, confirming a rapid, pulse-like rupture and a subtle curve in the slip path. This real-time visual data opens a new frontier in earthquake science, potentially transforming how we understand and predict seismic behavior.
articles.content:
During the midday Friday prayer hours on March 28, 2025, a magnitude 7.7 earthquake struck central Myanmar along the Sagaing Fault. With an epicenter close to Mandalay, the country's second-largest city, it was the most powerful earthquake to strike Myanmar in more than a century and the second deadliest in its modern history.

The cause was a strike-slip fault, in which two masses of earth "slip" past each other horizontally along a vertical fault plane. To an observer, it would look like the ground were split in two along a defined line, with both sides being wrenched past each other in opposite directions.

Previous seismological studies have inferred pulse-like rupture behavior and curved slip paths from the analysis of seismic data. However, because the recording instruments were at a considerable distance from the fault itself, these findings were indirect.

This time, however, a CCTV camera caught this slip in action, presenting a unique opportunity for a team researchers at Kyoto University to study the fault motion in real time. (See video link at bottom of article.)

The team applied a technique known as pixel cross-correlation to the CCTV footage to analyze the fault's movement frame-by-frame. Their analysis reveals that the fault slipped sideways 2.5 meters in just 1.3 seconds, with a maximum speed of 3.2 meters per second. The total sideways movement recorded during this earthquake is typical of strike-slip ruptures, but the short duration of the fault slip is a major discovery.

"The brief duration of motion confirms a pulse-like rupture, characterized by a concentrated burst of slip propagating along the fault, much like a ripple traveling down a rug when flicked from one end," says corresponding author Jesse Kearse.

The team's analysis also proves that the slip path was subtly curved, a finding which aligns with previous geological observations from faults around the world. This may suggest that such slips are typically curved, as opposed to being completely linear.

The study demonstrates that video-based monitoring of faults is a powerful tool for seismology, enabling unprecedented insights into earthquake behavior. Capturing this level of detail is fundamental to improving our understanding of earthquake processes and enhancing our ability to anticipate the ground shaking expected in future large events.

"We did not anticipate that this video record would provide such a rich variety of detailed observations. Such kinematic data is critical for advancing our understanding of earthquake source physics," says Kearse.

The next phase of their research will utilize physics-based models to investigate the factors that control fault behavior as revealed by this analysis.
articles.reasoning: While the earthquake itself is a natural disaster, the story focuses on the groundbreaking scientific and technological achievement of capturing real-time footage of fault slip, which advances earthquake science and could improve future prediction and safety measures.
articles.personality_title: Stunning footage captures Earth's powerful split in seconds
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
In March 2025, central Myanmar experienced a major earthquake measuring 7.7 on the Richter scale—the strongest in over a hundred years. This quake happened along the Sagaing Fault, where two large sections of the Earth’s crust slide past each other horizontally.

**What happened**
A CCTV camera near the fault line recorded the earthquake’s fault slipping by 2.5 meters in just seconds. Researchers at Kyoto University studied this rare video and discovered the fault moved in a quick, pulse-like way with a slight curve, revealing new details about how earthquakes unfold.

**Impact**
This real-time footage is a breakthrough for earthquake science. By seeing exactly how the fault shifted during the quake, scientists can better understand the mechanics of earthquakes, which may lead to improved prediction methods and safety plans that save lives.

**What's next step**
Scientists plan to gather more real-time data from fault lines worldwide using similar cameras. They will use this information to refine models that predict earthquake behavior and help communities prepare better for future quakes.

**One-sentence takeaway**
A rare video of a fault slipping during a powerful earthquake offers new hope for improving how we understand and predict these natural events.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des images impressionnantes capturent la puissante fissure de la Terre en quelques secondes
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
En mars 2025, le centre du Myanmar a subi un important séisme de magnitude 7,7, le plus fort depuis plus d’un siècle. Ce tremblement de terre s’est produit le long de la faille de Sagaing, où deux grandes plaques terrestres glissent horizontalement l’une contre l’autre.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Une caméra de vidéosurveillance près de la faille a filmé un glissement de 2,5 mètres en seulement quelques secondes. Les chercheurs de l’université de Kyoto ont étudié cette vidéo rare et découvert que la faille bougeait par impulsions rapides avec une légère courbure, révélant de nouveaux détails sur le déroulement des séismes.

**Impact**
Cette vidéo en temps réel est une avancée majeure pour la science des séismes. En voyant comment la faille s’est déplacée exactement, les scientifiques peuvent mieux comprendre les mécanismes des tremblements de terre, ce qui pourrait améliorer la prédiction et les plans de sécurité pour sauver des vies.

**Prochaine étape**
Les chercheurs prévoient de collecter davantage de données en temps réel sur des failles du monde entier grâce à des caméras similaires. Ils utiliseront ces informations pour affiner les modèles de prévision et aider les communautés à mieux se préparer.

**Conclusion en une phrase**
Une vidéo rare d’un glissement de faille pendant un puissant séisme offre un nouvel espoir pour mieux comprendre et prévoir ces événements naturels.
articles.personality_title_es: Impresionantes imágenes capturan la poderosa fisura de la Tierra en segundos
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
En marzo de 2025, el centro de Myanmar sufrió un gran terremoto de magnitud 7.7, el más fuerte en más de un siglo. Este sismo ocurrió a lo largo de la falla de Sagaing, donde dos grandes placas terrestres se deslizan horizontalmente una junto a la otra.

**Qué pasó**
Una cámara de CCTV cerca de la falla grabó un deslizamiento de 2,5 metros en solo segundos. Investigadores de la Universidad de Kioto estudiaron este video raro y descubrieron que la falla se movió de forma rápida y pulsante con una ligera curva, revelando nuevos detalles sobre cómo se desarrollan los terremotos.

**Impacto**
Este video en tiempo real es un avance para la ciencia de los terremotos. Al ver exactamente cómo se movió la falla durante el sismo, los científicos pueden entender mejor los mecanismos del mismo, lo que podría mejorar las predicciones y los planes de seguridad para salvar vidas.

**Próximo paso**
Los científicos planean recopilar más datos en tiempo real de fallas en todo el mundo utilizando cámaras similares. Usarán esta información para perfeccionar modelos que predigan el comportamiento sísmico y ayuden a las comunidades a prepararse mejor.

**Resumen en una frase**
Un video raro de un deslizamiento de falla durante un terremoto poderoso ofrece nueva esperanza para mejorar la comprensión y predicción de estos eventos naturales.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a cracked earth landscape showing two large, gently curved fault lines slipping sideways past each other by a clear 2.5-meter gap, with soft earth tones and subtle motion lines suggesting a quick pulse-like ripple traveling along the fault, set against a calm sky over a distant silhouette of Mandalay’s hills.

articles.title: Giant laser heats solid gold to 14 times its melting point
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 23 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02344-wA 50 nm thick sheet of solid gold was heated well beyond a theoretical limit, suggests new study — plus, what researchers think about the threat of nuclear war.
articles.content:
A 50 nm thick sheet of solid gold was heated well beyond a theoretical limit, suggests new study — plus, what researchers think about the threat of nuclear war.

You have full access to this article via your institution.

Download the Nature Podcast 23 July 2025

In this episode:

00:46 How hot can solid gold get?

A new study suggests that gold can be superheated far beyond its melting point without it becoming a liquid. Using an intense burst from a laser, a team heated a gold foil to 14 times its melting point, far beyond a theoretical limit put forward in previous studies. The team suggest that the speed at which they heated the gold allowed them to shoot past this limit, but there is scepticism about whether the team actually achieved the level of heating they report.

Research Article: White et al.

News and Views: Solid gold superheated to 14 times its melting temperature

10:05 Research Highlights

How island life led to huge wingspans for flying foxes, and how a sugary diet ‘rewires’ a mouse’s brain.

Research Highlight: How the world’s biggest bats got their enormous wingspans

Research Highlight: How sugar overload in early life affects the brain later

12:30 Researchers warn about the threat of nuclear war

With increasing political polarisation and more nuclear-armed nations, researchers are warning about the threat of nuclear war. Reporter Alex Witze has been speaking to scientists, and she told us about their chief concerns and how to avoid a conflict in an era of AI and misinformation.

News Feature: How to avoid nuclear war in an era of AI and misinformation

23:22 Briefing Chat

What a new AI model from China means for science, and why some dolphins use sponges to hunt.

Nature: ‘Another DeepSeek moment’: Chinese AI model Kimi K2 stirs excitement

Associated Press: Some Australian dolphins use sponges to hunt fish, but it’s harder than it looks

Subscribe to Nature Briefing, an unmissable daily round-up of science news, opinion and analysis free in your inbox every weekday.

Never miss an episode. Subscribe to the Nature Podcast on Apple Podcasts, Spotify, YouTube Music or your favourite podcast app. An RSS feed for the Nature Podcast is available too.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights a scientific breakthrough involving the heating of solid gold beyond theoretical limits, which represents progress in materials science and technology. Although it mentions concerns about nuclear war, the primary focus is on the advancement in understanding material properties under extreme conditions, which is positive and could have future technological applications.
articles.personality_title: Scientists heat solid gold to record-breaking temperatures using giant laser
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Scientists have long believed there’s a limit to how hot solid gold can get before it melts. Gold usually melts at around 1,064°C (1,947°F). Pushing beyond that temperature while keeping it solid seemed impossible—until now.

**What happened**
A new study used a powerful laser to heat an ultra-thin sheet of solid gold, just 50 nanometers thick, to a staggering 14 times its melting point. This means the gold reached temperatures far beyond what was thought possible without turning into liquid. The laser’s intense, quick burst supplied energy so fast that the gold’s atoms didn’t have time to rearrange into a liquid form.

**Impact**
This breakthrough helps scientists better understand how materials behave under extreme conditions. Knowing that gold can stay solid at such high heat opens doors to new technologies, like improved electronics and advanced manufacturing processes that require materials to withstand intense heat.

**What's next step**
Researchers plan to explore how other materials respond to extreme heat using similar laser techniques. They also want to study potential uses for this superheated state in real-world applications, including electronics, energy, and materials science.

**One-sentence takeaway**
A giant laser has shown that solid gold can survive heat far beyond its melting point, unlocking new possibilities for science and technology.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des scientifiques chauffent de l'or solide à des températures record grâce à un laser géant
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Les scientifiques pensaient depuis longtemps qu’il y avait une limite à la température que l’or solide pouvait atteindre avant de fondre. L’or fond normalement à environ 1 064°C. Aller au-delà tout en restant solide semblait impossible, jusqu’à aujourd’hui.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Une nouvelle étude a utilisé un laser puissant pour chauffer une feuille ultra-fine d’or solide, de seulement 50 nanomètres d’épaisseur, à une température 14 fois supérieure à son point de fusion. Cela signifie que l’or a atteint des températures bien plus élevées que prévu sans devenir liquide. L’impulsion brève et intense du laser a donné de l’énergie si rapidement que les atomes d’or n’ont pas eu le temps de se réarranger en liquide.

**Impact**
Cette avancée aide les scientifiques à mieux comprendre le comportement des matériaux dans des conditions extrêmes. Savoir que l’or peut rester solide à de telles chaleurs ouvre la voie à de nouvelles technologies, comme des composants électroniques améliorés et des procédés de fabrication avancés nécessitant des matériaux résistants à la chaleur intense.

**Prochaine étape**
Les chercheurs prévoient d’étudier comment d’autres matériaux réagissent à la chaleur extrême en utilisant des techniques laser similaires. Ils souhaitent aussi explorer les applications possibles de cet état de surchauffe dans la vie quotidienne, notamment en électronique, énergie et science des matériaux.

**Conclusion en une phrase**
Un laser géant a démontré que l’or solide peut supporter une chaleur bien supérieure à son point de fusion, ouvrant de nouvelles perspectives pour la science et la technologie.
articles.personality_title_es: Científicos calientan oro sólido a temperaturas récord usando un láser gigante
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Durante mucho tiempo, los científicos creyeron que había un límite a qué tan caliente podía ponerse el oro sólido antes de derretirse. El oro normalmente se derrite a unos 1,064°C. Superar esa temperatura sin que se vuelva líquido parecía imposible, hasta ahora.

**Qué pasó**
Un nuevo estudio utilizó un láser potente para calentar una lámina ultra delgada de oro sólido, de solo 50 nanómetros de grosor, a una temperatura 14 veces mayor que su punto de fusión. Esto significa que el oro alcanzó temperaturas mucho más altas de lo pensado sin fundirse. El pulso rápido y fuerte del láser entregó energía tan rápido que los átomos del oro no tuvieron tiempo de reorganizarse en líquido.

**Impacto**
Este avance ayuda a los científicos a entender mejor cómo se comportan los materiales en condiciones extremas. Saber que el oro puede permanecer sólido a temperaturas tan altas abre nuevas oportunidades para tecnologías, como la mejora de electrónicos y procesos avanzados de fabricación que requieren materiales resistentes al calor intenso.

**Próximo paso**
Los investigadores planean estudiar cómo otros materiales responden al calor extremo usando técnicas similares con láser. También quieren explorar posibles usos para este estado de sobrecalentamiento en aplicaciones reales, incluyendo electrónica, energía y ciencia de materiales.

**Conclusión en una frase**
Un láser gigante ha demostrado que el oro sólido puede soportar calor mucho más allá de su punto de fusión, abriendo nuevas posibilidades para la ciencia y la tecnología.
